text:
Bottle from Bierkompass!

Pours deep black with a tiny brown head. Aroma of coffee, honey and caramel. Taste has strong roasted malts, coffee, caramel and some sweetish honey notes as well as dark dried fruits. Finish is very roasty, alcoholic, slight sweet with dark fruit notes.

interesting beer...alternating between a bittersweet imperial stout, strong hoppy black ale, and something else entirely. the finish seals the deal (after the roasted, bitter chocolate, honey taste up front) you get obvious cedar in the finish. unique for sure."

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2015 Honey-flavored and oak-aged, but otherwise very typical black IPA, the first beer in a series of four in which three breweries participate. Highly hopped with Mt. Rainier, Citra and Simcoe. Beige, creamy, sticky head, colour very opaque brown, near black. Aroma of coffee, grapefruit, mango, leather, bitter honey, cedar wood, liquorice. Soft dry taste, smooth and supple without the oily texture that would typify a heavy stout, spicy, woody, roasted bitterness increasing towards the finish, complex and very, very dry in the end. I bet this would make an excellent companion for a good cigar.

Boltz with the share. Can from Boltz. Pours black with thin tan head. The nose is fruiter than OR with dark fruits, roast, hops. The taste is dark fruits, cocoa, coffee and grapefruit. Medium mouthfeel. I like this one slightly better than OR. It seemed more complex. 3.9
Bottle shared by oRos. Pours very dark brown with no head. Aroma is hoppy. Med body. Flavor is dark malt, herbal hop, some chocolate. Finishes dry and earthy. Quite tasty.
Bottle shared by oRos. Pours dark brown with a tiny tan head and a chocolate and treacle aroma. There is a very tasty dark chocolate flavor with a bitter finish.
Bottle from Ibrew2or3. Pours black with brownish head. Taste is chocolate, roasted malts, earthy hops and dry finish.

12oz bottle thanks to Glouglouburp in a tulip. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, some sweetness from the honey, a little chocolate, light wood, and some floral and lightly citrusy hops. Flavor the same. Average to smooth texture. A pretty good beer.

12oz bottle, thanks to FlandersNed. Cap is marked "1-11". Black color. Good thin brown head. Short ropes and dots of lace, a nice good spread. Nice honey to the aroma, good dark roast, light burnt malts. Good light smoke. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, big sweet, light bite in the finish. Nice spice and wood notes. Earthy hop bitterness. Bigger body, kind of chewy. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Lightly drying finish. As it is now, decent big black IPA. Malty sweetness in the finish is a bit much, but I very much like the honey and wood notes.

Bottle shared at the Theydon Bois Roma Pre-Nuptuals Tasting at Ma Che. Pours dark brown-black with a fine, frothy cream head. Some spicy pine in the nose, burnt toast, earth, faint grapefruit. Medium sweet flavor with mellow dry and burnt wood, dark chocolate, baking cocoa, some piney bitterness, alcohol, grass. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Moderate warmth to finish with burnt grass, baking cocoa, straight dirt, pine, lime and grapefruit. Some spicy cedar, too. Hefty, nice.

Bottle, Theydon Bois Roma Pre-Nuptuals Tasting at Ma Che, 22/06/13. Thanks to Leighton for hunting down another Black IPA rate in Roma!
Dark black with a thin off white head that dissipates to a film.
Nose is dark roast, bitter chocolate, earthy hops, touch of booze.
Taste comprises a good roast dose, bitter hops, dark toffee, fruit notes, booze, sugars.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, dark fruit and hop bitterness in a roasted finish.
A fairly big beer - a DCDA ! Lots going on and pulls together well!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pitch black in colour, almost black foam. A bit hoppy but a lot of licorice and a nice sweetness makes this ber quite well balanced though the high alcohol level

Black as hell, brun skum, dufter af honning, smager sødligt, kaffe, ristet malt, let bitter eftersmag med kaffe

Free Føroyar!!!

Pours jet black with no head and very little noticeable carbonation.  Nose is molasses, toffee and vanilla. Flavor is dark fruit and toffee.  There is almost no indication of the high ABV.  A really nice beer.  Id forgotten about this one in my cellar and am unsure whether it has changed over time by virtue of the hops fading.  Even if it has, it is still a solid beer.

Bottle. Pours Deep opaque ruby black with very little head, even after a vigorous pour. Mostly just a ring of brown foam, although it does contribute some lacing. Aroma is very stouty with roasted malts, chocolate, and molasses. Flavor is very chocolate and roasty, with notes of citrus and pine mixed in. Quite sweet, medium bitter, lingering bitter aftertaste. Medium to full body, creamy, tongue coating oily mouthfeel. Flat carbonation. Very interesting beer, not sure why its not a hoppy stout tho.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a short lasting small tan head. Aroma is intense with cedar, hard roasted malt, plum, raisin, honey, licorice,  
Taste is moderate+ sweet and near heavy bitter. Body is medium, texture is syrupy, carbonation is soft+. Finishes caramel sweet, alcoholic and malty astringent.

Bottle. Dark brown with a minimal beige head that leaves lacing. Aroma is vinous, cedar, honey, sweet grain, bubblegum, citrus, black pepper. Taste is heavy sweet and medium bitter. Close to full body, thick oily texture, soft carbonation. Sticky vinous finish with warming alcohol.
pours jet black with a thin white head, aroma of dank resinous hops, citrus and pine as well as a roasty characteristic.  Taste follows, bitter yet slightly sweet. not bad

Bottle shared at Delirium Hoppy Loft, side by side with Or.  Pours black with a small thick tan head.  Aroma of rich chocolate, roasted malt, molasses, light coffee and a touch of vanilla.  Flavour is heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter.  Mouthfeel is thick and oily.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.  A little fuller and more intense than the Or.
Bottle at CCB Day, Sätila 2012-07-07. Black beer with a small beige head. Raisin, plum and malty aroma. Similar flavour. A nice beer.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, july 19th 2012.
Black colored, small breamy brown head.
Aroma of chocolate, wood, citrus. Roasty taste with american hops, honey, dark fruits. Warm and vicious body, lasting dry bitterness. A really good beer.

12 oz. bottle via normyk.  Pours very dark brown to black with a small tan head.  The nose has quite a bit of porter character with roasted malts, chocolate, molasses and dark fruit, and adds the nice touch of cedar (mild) and some hops.  The flavor is more roasted malt, chocolate, molasses, cedar, dark fruit and some hop bite at the back.  Mouth feel is full and there is quite a bit of sweetness from the honey.  Bumped a tenth after having Or.

Bottle at Man in the Moon, Stockholm.

Thick, sticky, oily fluid. Black as night. Small sweetness, sage and honey in taste. The bitterness comes late. Nice black IPA, the ABV is well hidden.
Great black IPA.  really rich and toasty with a nice hop bite that has a lot of pine and some citrus.  Quite tasty and drinkable for the crazy high ABV.  Loved it.

Bottle shared @ Timos/tkrjukoffs CCB Day tasting on July 7, 2012.Very dark brown to black color, brown head. Sweet, roasted, grainy, some spice and cheese, also alcohol scent. Sweet, malty, honey, smooth taste, alcohol. Smooth lean mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 355 ml bottle shared @ tkrjukoffs CCB Day tasting. Pours hazy black with a small brownish white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sweet and malty with liquorice fudge, sweet dark rye bread, alcohol, prunes, coffee, pine, grapefruit juice, hay and burnt caramel. Taste is sweet, bitter and slightly metallic with roasted malts, grapefruit juice, coffee, grass, pine, black pepper, resinous wood, bitter chocolate, alcohol and prunes. Mouthfeel is tiny sticky sweet, slightly oily bitter and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with roasted malts, grapefruit juice, coffee, grapes, rye bread and wood.

Thx to Palme for this one ! 
Head: smalle, firm, espresso 
Colour: almost black 
Smell: chocolat, Anise, herbs, licquorice, high alcohol, black cherries 
Taste: start is herbal, slight amount of coffee, high bitterness, small hops, something wineous, a touch of sour, some alcohol that burns the mouth, some woody and spicey notes , end is dry with a good amount of hops in the flavour, also oily textured, rather nice one !
POurs jet black with deep caramel notes.  Sticky on the mouth with a caramelized grain/malt flavor that drives to a very long dry finish.

35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 12.03.2010
Aroma is rather roasted with some hops, resin and chocolate. Flavour is somewhat ashy with hops, roastiness, coffee and chocolate. Very well roasted and good, could be an imperial stout as well. Better than Or.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 Bottle to celebrate Nicks 38th. Happy birthday bro ! Great looking tan head atop a pitch black body. Nose is very spicy with heavy chocolate and molasses running through it. Only a touch sweet with some vanilla tones. I remember the Or being a little sweeter. Taste is taken over by heavy cocoa and spices. The cedar cask comes through brilliantly. A touch of molasses, liquorice and vanilla to top it off. Unbelievable beer and not many black IPAs compare to this or the Or. Amazing
Bottle. Super dark pour. Roasty woody nose and taste. Slightly better than Or in my opinion.

Bottle, from trade with HenrikSoegaard. A dark, dark brown beer topped by a small, beige head. Roasted malts, soy sauce, some alcohol, a nice hoppyness, some beefstock and a touch of roasted black pepper in the aroma. The flavor is on the roasted malty side, but with a pleasant citrus peel-like hoppyness bringing some balance. Soy sauce, beef stock and a touch of alcohol too. Full-bodied and lightly warming. Bitter finish with some citrus peel and roasted malts. A quite wonderful one. 110916

50 cl bottle.
Rated on 20110312.
Pours black color with small head. Aroma of ripe fruits and malts. Flavor of malts, fruits and some chocolate.
5425

Cellared bottle for a year. Poured a dark black with beige head. Notes of stick toffee, floral and juicy hops, very oily on the palate. Aromas of honey and chocolate shavings. Finishes smooth and warming. Excellent black ipa.

Pours black with a short lived tan head.
The nose is rich with toffe and malt, there are also some bready notes. 
The taste is surprisingly mild for the color and nose. There is a nice honey flavor, and a slight taste of bittering hops.
The mouthefeel is realy smooth, with a slight creaminess. The carbonation is light and the finish is warming with a tinge of bitterness.

From notes.  

Black pour with a tan edge and a creamy mocha froth.

Creamy milk chocolate, roasted malt, dark chocolate, espresso, spicy pine hop aroma.

Creamy and sweet up front, with roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate soon after.  Mostly pine hops help finish the flavor.

The body is definitely full, for any style.  The high ABV is not noticeable anywhere in the flavor though.

This Black IPA will hit you hard, but it tastes pretty good.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is peaches, roasted malt, coffee. Flavour is licorice, alcohol, roasted malt, hop, coffee. Complex nice beer.

Pours black with no head. Aroma is molasses, licorice, tobacco and prunes. Taste is heavy malt & leather up front with a hoppy bitterness in the finish. Full viscous mouthfeel. Reminds me of an old leather jacket. Interesting. Would go well with a cigar.

My bottle [12oz] shared with garthicus & HogTownHarry -- c/o Glouglouburp. Dec. 13, 2011. Pours a very dark brown with a small lasting bubbly tan head. Nice aroma of resiny leafy hops, light smoke, dark malt and some chocolate. Flavour has hops galore along with lightly roasted dark malt, chocolate, a hint of peat and a big bitter finish. Medium bodied, almost-creamy mouthfeel. Great stuff.

Bottle. Black and viscous pour with scant brown head and no lace. The intense, dense aroma has character of being oxidized or rusty even though its new, and thats not a bad thing here. Dark cherry skins, tarred and charred. Bittersweet cocoa powder and ganache. Raisins, and black currants. Very soft mouthfeel. Smooth in spite of being intense. Lots of coffee and deep dark roasted espresso. Good balance of fruity acidity with the dark roasted, almost burnt flavors. South American coffee cherries and char. Compelling, more so because of the concept of either/or.
Danish beer enthusiasts Aarhus south, dark IPA tasting: Black colour with fine brown head. Roasted malty aroma. Very rich dark beer with an intense hop flavor. Burning aftertaste.

Wonderful deep chocolate notes out of the bottle, and spicy-piney hops as well. Smell luscious. Thin mocha head that disappears quickly. Mouthfeel is velvety and covering. Flavors as just amazing...spicy wood, dark mocha, chocolate, sweet honey and whole hop flavors. A bit of heat near the end, but this is a beer I really enjoy.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, shared with BBGTC. Pours an oily black body with a small creamy off-white head. Nose is deep roasty malts, licorice, roasted nuts, wood, bushes (cedar? Im too unfamiliar with this type of wood to actually recognize, but something special is going on here...), booze, dark syrup, honey and hints of dark fruits, grass and pine. Wow. This is really a delicious blend of aromas. Taste is licorice, dark malts, roasty nuts and wood, with hints of dark fruits and alcohol. Some tar-like roasty notes in the finish. Smooth carbonation, slick mouthfeel. Although the taste does not quite live up the the amazing aroma, this is one helluva brew - complex, yet extremely smooth at the same time and well integrated as far as the high ABV is concerned. Would like more of this.

Quite much a pitch black colour with a mediumsized beigeish brown head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malts, mild ashes, coffee and some slight fruity and hoppy notes. Flavour is floral hops, some roasted malts, mild ashes and some chocolate. Also smoked wet wooden notes

Entering old rates. 12oz bottle. Couleur brune foncée, col beige. Arôme est houblonné avec un bouquet très prononcé de houblon citra et pin résineux laissant ce côté agrumes; pamplemousse et citron donner la mesure. Je note aussi un malt léger grillé et caramel qui se fond bien dans la masse de houblon herbacé. Lusage du cèdre étant un peu la signature de CCB reste modéré et rajoute une petite pointe dépice le miel quant à lui est discret et donne juste ce quil faut de douceur et de profile naturel à la bière.  Seul regret, que la bière soit si forte en alcool et aussi son prix qui est assez onéreux.

12oz bottle thanks to KevSal.  Pours darkest brown with a small tan head.  Roasty and ashy aroma typical of Cigar City, with some resinous hops and lots of dark chocolate.  The flavor is great, maybe a bit aged, but its aged well.  Chocolate, molasses, anise, and resinous hops.  Medium-full bodied with soft carbonation and mild syrupiness.  Solid, tasty beer overall.

12oz bottle shared by blankboy with me and garthicus.  Deep ruby-black, smallish wispy beige head.  Black IPA all right - resin, cedar, oily malt, herbal, a bit boozy, acidic and leafy - a little vanilla with oak tanin sharpness.  Taste follows, way more cedar, a bit boozy;  slick, average body, somewhat astringent - long "dark" woody finish.  Nice!!

Thanks to Blankboy. Appearance: oily black, medium brown head. Aroma: Rich chocolate, lovely peat, smokey, mocha, roast coffee. Flavour: Rich chocolate, tons of malt, zippy hop, cedar, sticky, lots of peat and hops, just lovely. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle thanks to markwise?  poured black with a beige head.  aroma was chocolate, pine, and fudge.  flavor was much the same plus some coffee.  body was light and slick.

12o bottle. Dark, viscous black with pretty much no head, ring of brown around the rim. Definitely does not smell like a Black IPA - more like a big dark old ale. Roasted and sweet malts, bittersweet chocolate, anise, booze, molasses, raspberry.Full bodied, below average carbonation but good, hot very/prickly (not detectable on the nose) and sweet, very smooth, bitterness finally appear on the finish along with a huge sweet and tasty malt profile. Finish lasts a while, fairly complex, get smoke and anise. Reminds me of an aged expedition

Bottle 355ml from Allen thanks, a dark beer with a medium brownish head. Nose is very roasted like, resin and alcoholic. Aroma is fruity, sweet, creamy, dark chocolate like, lovely body with a very strong, long and intense roasted aftertaste. Quite complex beer with licorice, dry grapes, grapefruit notes, roasted, caramel notes, so creamy, so drinkable.

Pours tar black with a tan head.  Aroma of licorice, dark chocolate, honey and fig.  Thick stout-like body with excellent lacing.  Flavor of licorice, honey, chocolate, fig, and a hint of hop bitter ending.  Great beer!
Heavy malty aroma. Small,frothy, light brown head. Fair lacing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Black body. Heavy bitter and very much chocolate flavor. Medium palate.

Bottle shared by GrOve.
Smoke, cocoa, bittersweet chocolate. Smooth, pleasant, well balanced.

12 fl. oz bottle, kindly shared by GrOve. Jet black. Low tanned head. Complex aroma. Fruity hops and resin, rich dark malts featuring black chocolate, burnt caramel and licorice. Tones of wood, ash and tar. Full malt body. Dark burnt caramel and cocoa/choco. Solid ongoing bitterness. Wood and licorice notes. Roast, spiced/ashy malts and lingring bitterness in the finish. Packed and complex with super drinkability.

Small brown head. Opaque black body. Cocoa and earth aroma with raisiny fruity caramel notes. Dry-sweet resiny roasty earthy taste with chocolatey alcohol notes. Full-bodied. Hottish mouthfeel. Dry cocoa and earth aftertaste with resiny fruity notes. Honey and pepper, too. Excellent, and highly drinkable. (0.355l bottle shared by gr0ve.)

Black pour with a scattered slick of tan foam.  Aroma is honey, molasses, light cedar, plum, raisin, and a heavy, barley wine style malt backbone.  Wow - taste is clean cedar up front followed by molasses, sweet malt, bitter hops, and licorice.  The hop bitterness and cedar lingers after each sip.  The taste is much better and cleaner than anticipated after the aroma.  I like it - good beer.

Bottle, at home. Pours black, 1-finger dark tan head; spotty lacing. Nose is black licorice, smoke, gentle hops, graphite, light bacon. Less Black IPA than CCB Stout. Not a bad aroma, just not really Black IPA to my tongue. Flavours of bacon, graphite, soapy hops, smoke, very rich, loads of coffee and tar. Im really divided as to how to score this: As a beer, this is a fantastic brew, worthy of a score in the low 4s; on the other hand, as a Bglack IPA, this is a rather weak example of the style, and could score in the low 3s or even high 2s as a Black IPA. Im giving this a 3.9, as its too tasty to score any lower, but too not-really-a-black-IPA to score it any higher.

Bouteille de 12 oz obtenue via Fred82. Arôme: Odeur de céréales grillées et dhoublons avec une pointe de chocolat. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dhoublons résineux avec une pointe de céréales grillées et dalcool. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dalcool en arrière goût. (Rating #3887)

Deep pitch black coloured body with a viscous feel and almost no head at all. Aroma of oak, honey, roasted malt, alcohol, figs and quite a bit of licorice - not much hops really, those REALLY come through on the or. Medium-bodied; Assertive roastiness with a lot of hops in the initial taste and they both quickly fade to an oaky, viscous dry vanilla and almost porter like feel. Aftertaste shows the alcohol warmth more than anything with a bit of toffee and caramel leftover and some mild hops finishing off the back end. Overall, a nice and strong beer that is interesting and well worth sampling. Sampled horizontally with the Or beer - which is far hoppier and more well rounded than this one, but neat to try both of these at the same time - next time im in Florida, Ill try to find the other two. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Knightly Spirits (Orange Blossom) in Orlando, Florida on 15-November-2010 sampled at home in Washington on 16-October-2011.
Pitch blak pour that had the aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, honey annd grass.  Flavors match the arommas with a nice blend of roast and sweetness.  Not much hops come through unlike the Or beer.

@ ACBF 2011. The aroma has a lot of hopfruitiness and dried malty fruitiness, chocolate, wine and roast. Black coloured beer with a thin, beige head. The taste is roasty, bitter, has raisins, chocolate and a lingering bitterness. Full bodied. Nice one.
Bottle.Pours black with an off-white head.Aroma of peach, caramel , roasted malt and coffee.Flavor is sweet and roasted with some caramel and peach.Medium body, average carbonation
Bottle, thanx to Nisse666. Pours black with a small, light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, hops and spices. Flavor of hops, pepper and dark malt. Pretty bitter finish, alcohol well hidden.

355 ml bottle, from Ølbutikken (or possibly Høkeren), Copenhagen. ABV is 11.2%. Pitch black colour, minimal tan head. Lovely complex aroma with roasty and vinous notes, coffee, dark chocolate, liquorice, cedar wood and honey.  Warming mouthfeel. The flavour is very malty and sweet with strong roasty notes, coffee, molasses, honey, wood, dark bitter chocolate and liquorice. The sweetness is to some extent balanced by resinous American hops. A mighty fine beer!

Bottle. Pours black, with a small but creamy head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee and toffee, with notes of oak, pine and citrus/ orange peel. Flavour is coffee, chocolate and roasted malts, with apples and oranges, and a sweet wood oakiness and leather. The finish is hoppy, with grapefruit and orange peel.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2011 12 oz. bottle, sent by Glouglouburp (thanks Dany), split with Matts_Property, pours black with a reddish tinge and a tiny ring of tan head. Beautiful aroma of sherry-like liqueur, some roasted malts, subtle cedar notes and some honey. Flavour of cedar coated roasted malt, slight liqueur, some honey and booze - boozy, cedar, bitter finish. Medium-to-full complexity and an oily palate. As with the Jail Alai Cedar Aged, the cedar is not too enjoyable a quality to me and this beer feels like theyve tried to throw too many elements into one beer. Still great for what it is.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 12oz bottle split with mcberko. Pours a solid black/brown with a red tint, and no head. Aroma of boozy liqueur, candied sugars, molasses, wood. Flavour of candied sugar and darker fruits initially, followed by a woody dryness, hoppy bitterness, and a boozy warming finish. Honey coating mouth feel. Very nice.

33 cl bottle from Barley Wine, Copenhagen. Black liquid with reddish hue and small tan head. Aroma is woodier than Or, and more balanced and soft. Of course also hoppy and roasty but maltier with notes of caramel, toffee and similar malty notes. Taste is also dryer and heavily bitter and roasty, malty notes. Much more balanced than Or. Really nice. Medium bodied with ok carbonation. Really, really nice and quite malty.

0.33l bottle. This is a really black beer with a small sidesticking chocolate head. Lots of aroma; roasted malts, really hopy, sweet honey, light grassy and also lots and lots  of leather and some hints of sweet chocolate. Thick and velvety mouthfeeling, really full-bodied and low on the carbonation. Really nice and roasted flavors, also some light sweetness that I guess comes from the honey. Notes of dark chocolate, cocoa and more roasted malts. Ends mild hoppy with a longlasting roasted, light sweet and not least warming aftertaste. Really nice, and Im looking forward to trying the next in the series!
Great brew, pours a black color with tiny tan head. Nose is coffee, cocoa, hops, and honey. On the palate it has the same with cedar notes. Awesome.

On bottle. Chocolate and coffee smell. A strong beer not so easy to drink. The coffee taste is more noticeable as you drink as well as for the hop and licorice tastes. The color is black and the froth is not persistent so much, actually it decreases as you drink, becoming so flat. I can say it is complex enough and it is a very good job.

Bottle. Aroma is wood, hop, liquorice, caramel, (roasted) malt, touch of barleywine sweetness. Flavour starts with deep bitterness of hop and liquorice, instantly followed by strong malty caramel sweetness, notes found in barleywine, fruits, some spice. Then back to hops and loads of cedar. Intense and awesome.
Bottle. Black colour with large creamy light brown fully lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt with notes of chocolate and coffee. Sweet spicy flavor. Creamy palate.

Poured from an 12 ounce bottle into a Spiegelau tulip. Purchased along with Either at Cigar City Brewing taproom on 11/20/10.

Appearance: Pours a coffee black color with a 1finger foamy tan head consisting of tiny carbonation bubbles. Excellent lacing.

Smell: Piney hops, sweet roasted malt and a touch of molasses.

Taste: Pine dominates up front then sweet malt and a cedar and white pepper in the middle before ending with toasted malt and burnt toast at the finish. Aftertaste is a mix of burnt toast and hoppy bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a fairly high amount of carbonation. Goes down smooth.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. This is a sipper due to the high ABV%, but you wont have any trouble finishing it off in the least.

Overall: Very good beer overall. I actually liked this a little better than Or, which may be due to the fact that a little age has taken some of the bite off it. Another strong offering from Cigar City.

Bottle from Barley Wine shared in Sätila
AR: apricots, caramel
AP: dark, beige head
F: peppery, coffee, apricots, chocolate, caramel its better then Or - more sweetnes and caramel

Bottle 33 cl, courtesy of Nisse666. Pours pitch black with a creamy shortlived brown head leaving lace. Aroma is sweet, dark fruits, raisins, spicy, acidy and malty. Flavor is very malty, sweet, alcohol and pungeant, like aroma. Finishes tart sweet and dark fruity.
Bottle, thanks to Nisse666. Black beer, brown head. Hoppy milky aroma, grassy, some perfume, sweet ish and somewhat spicy. Hoppy grassy flavor, metal, perfume, hay and chocolate. Nice beer!

Bottle from Tampa WHoleFoods.  Next to Or.  Into my newly acquired CCB snifter.  Paled in comparison to Or.  Pours black with tan head that does not last. Aroma is alcohol, bittering hops, and grain. Medium mouthfeel. Flavor is rather astringent, roast, more wood than Or and resinous hops.   Alcohol seemed way more in your face than Or

Bottle at home bought at Vinmonopolet Vika
Pitch black, medium tanned head. Nice lacings. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, caramel and wood. I miss the fruity aroma from Or but its still very nice. Also molasses. Taste is massive of chocolate, caramel, toffee and coffee. Full malt body, good sweetness. Feel is extremely oily, for me this is excuisite and gorgeous.Finish has a nice hop bitterness - But i have to compare it a bit to Or again. If this is a Black IPA i will say Or is much closer to that - so maybe it shouldnt be called a black ipa?

01-07-11 Bouteille 341ml: Noire, légèrement effervescente et avec un mince filet de mousse. Arômes très complexes de grillés, de chocolat, de pamplemousse, de cèdre et de boisé... Bière extrèmement originale et offrant une explosion de saveurs rares. Légèrement sucrée, avec une moyenne amertume et une petite acidité aux notes de pamplemousse. Corps moyen, avec une texture  entre le léger et le crémeux. Asser bonne carbonisation. Finale très spéciale aux notes surette et acide dagrumes, mélangé au chocolat et au cèdre. On peut vraiment percevoir, contrairement à la jai alai humidor, leffet du vieillissement en cèdre toasté espagnol. Bière extrèmement plaisante à boire.
Bottle next to Or. Black pour with beige head. Some earthy, pine, and citrus tones with a mild warming overtone, weaker of the two black IPAs.
Bottle from Ølbutikken. Black with a brown, creamy film. Roasted, milky, alcoholic, light wooden nose. Sweet, liquorice, pepper, sandalwood, bitter mouth. Full body. Alcoholic warmth.

Thanks Ben for sending. Pours a viscous black brew with two fingers of chestnut brown head. Nose is cedary, kind of musty with hints of bakers chocolate and coffee. 36cl, Cigar City version, brewed at CC, new exclusive American brew Anno 2010, with honey, thx to Jeppe!, very complex bitter brew, slightly roasted and fruity, not too heavy, very balanced, hazy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!
Bottle at Joes, thanks for sharing. Another taste at Alvinne CBF 2011. Very finely tuned, soft taste. Alcohol very well hidden and a good full body with nice carbonation.

from Erzbierschof.ch - black beer with a poor head retention,; aroma of black chocolate, licorice and honey; pretty fairly hoppy; thick and full-bodied; a robust sweetness and a solid bitterness; long chocolatey and honeyish, hoppy finish - robust and contemplative

Smell: Honey, raisins, grass, tobaco, plums
Taste: Bitter chocolait, honey, grapefruit, toffe, vanilla, banana kids candy.
Mouthfeel: Soft, some nice hop bitterness.
Notes: Its like a well hopped Stormakts Porter. I love this beer.

Pours like Or
Aroma is also very much like his brother, but the chocolate and dark fruits are more up front. Taste is a little more sweet, but almost all the same. 
I had expected a bigger difference between the two.

Bottle at Bishops folkungagatan.
Aroma of hops, wood and caramell.
Taste of wood, perfume, chocolate and licorice. I like that the hops don´t dominates this beer as they usualy do in black ipas.

Bottle. I must say that this beer was one of my best ever Black IPA experiences ever. The cedar agening has made it móre elegant and not just macho agressive. On the other side i felt that the wood notes took over a little too much after a few sips... still very good though.
I liked the Or better. This one was a bit sour compared to the Or. Its a good dark beer, but definitly not my favorite.
Wow, the alcohol was well hidden in this one. Aroma and flavor is pretty well balanced too. Not overly roasty like a hoppy porter. Nice hop flavor with a bit of sweetness, cocoa and toast. Nice.
Bottle at The Bishops Arms, Södermalm. Pours black with a tan head. Intenbse bitter chocolate, a little bit roast, a hint of honey. Full-bodied. A late-night treat.

12oz bottle from Capones, Norristown. Thanks, Matt! Fairly dusty blackish brown pour with a nice thick foamy head, and some serious sticky lacing. Nose is very big and assertive, with resinous hops being foremost initially: piney, lime and pineapple, and hint of sweet simcoe. Body is fairly full, with the healthy carbonation seeming to enliven all the flavors. Theres a ton going on too, with honey, toffee, hints of molasses, and grain along with the strong citrus and hops presence. But instead of giving the brew more range and character, it ended up for me being a bit too sweet and grainy, with the result being that the roasts and the hop bite were flattened a bit. Still enjoyable but was hoping for more.

Bottle courtesy of Doodler (thanks Scott!) poured a clear dark brown nearly black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of roastiness, licorice, honey, cedar, milk chocolate and light citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roastiness, bitter chocolate, licorice, light honey, light cedar and a hint of citrus with a smooth lingering roasty chocolate finish.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2011 Bottle. An opaque black beer, with a small. frothy, almost fully collapsing brown head. The aroma is moderately malty, moderately hoppy. There are notes of roasted grain, chocolate, pine, grapefruit, smoke, cedar, spices, with some peppery hints and a touch of honey and alcohol. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Almost full body, round mouthfeel, lively carbonation, very long finish with nearly heavy bitterness, moderately alcoholic. The first words that come to my mind are challenging and stimulating, The honey is a nice complement in both aroma and flavor, The malts taste more roasted in the flavour, to the point of being burnt, charred, but pleasant, The hops shine in the finish, but not only, the cedar gives a spiciness thats not overwhelming, but instead adds complexity to the product. From the very few things Ive tasted so far Cigar City might probably be in my top 5, if not top 3 brewery in the USA.

Black color/ tan head.  Nice big vanilla bean, coffee, medium roast malt, pine sap, chocolate aromas. Medium bodied with soft co2. Pine sap, vanilla, dark coffee, dry black malt flavors, mild boozy twang to finish--good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty thick caramel aroma with hoppy hints. Thick roasted malty chocolate flavor with hopy hints. Has a roasted malty hoppy bitter finish.
Sweet full bodied beer, hops and honey on the nose, the honey really comes through on the flavor, cedar is subtle in the palate

[355ml bottle, courtesy of cgarvieuk] Pours totally black and with a small cream-coloured head. Bitter, good coffee aromas coming out on the nose, with some earthy spice. Darker and more coffee evident than the Or (sampled alongside). Pretty hefty stuff for a Black IPA  unless its a DBIPA? Smoother than the Or Black Ale, so slightly nicer in my book [08052011]

Thanks Smith4498. Definitely black. Aroma is mainly cedar and some roastiness. Swirling arouses some dish soap. Flavor starts with that characteristic carafa special psuedo roastiness. Finish comes with the cedar, and eventually the carafa fades back in.

bottle at home ... dark black ... thin tan head ... soft coffee roast nose ...dark malts ... toffee roats ... coffee roast ... little chocolate ... softer than the or ... more chocolate ... juicy plums ...

7 May 2011, bottle at one of cgarvieuks legendary tastings. really dark brown/black, no head. smoky, slightly peaty/earthy, coffee stout nose. med/thin body and mildly fizzy. coffee fades to a med dark chocolate. bitter chocolate finish. nice.

Tap, Churchkey. Mahogany and almost black.  Soapy and almost Windex hops and grapefruit in the aroma with some slight roast. Lots of soapy hops, tobacco, and chocolate and a cedary finish.  Dry.  Silkier, medium body. Aggressive, but balanced in a lot of ways.

Bottle at Churchkey, shared with some dude named Mike.  Slightly darker, bigger head, variegated beige.  Aroma of dark milk chocolate with a burnt edge.  Taste is smooth chocolate with a burnt edge, with bourbon, vanilla, and a cigar box finish.  Very nice.

Bottle; Pour is fairly dark black with a khaki head in this glass- So firstly ; a black ipa seems questionable to me as well, and not because of the ABV. I couldnt help but think ; heavily hopped cedar aged imperial stout, but what do I really know. What I can say for sure is that the OR is the better brew, having them both side by side. But only slightly. In this brew, you will find burned toast, honey, chocolate, licorice and a bitter hop profile that seems to present itself at various moments. The cedar imparts interest, but I suppose my mouth is used to it at this point, as this is the 3rd brew with that element. Anyway, on to my OR review.

Bottle that was kindly passed on by Jan (Fonefan) many thanks Jan, shared with Peter Fowler, Shoulder of Mutton at tasting at his pub 28.04.11    Pours black, really black, shark eye black in fact with a beige head. Really roasty, robust in the mouth, liqourice, and dark chocolate. Very tasty but lacking the smoothness of the OR that we tried it alongside.  A7 A5 T7 P4 Ov14  3.7

12 bottle from a yet another great trade with DCHMELA!
a fine dark black pour with a thin head. Rich Raosty start. Cedar hops chocolate and little coffee. Cant wait to try the or. (not to mention the Niether nor!) thanks Dave.

Bottled 355ml. Shared with Anton Flükiger. It pours a beautiful nicely tanned beer with a lacing light beige head. The aroma is inviting, reminiscent of caramel, cedar and hops which are high on alpha acids. Alcoholic, faintly metallic and remarkably strong. The roasted malt components are quite subdued. Full bodied. Strong bitterness. Dry finish which makes you eager to take another sip. Nice but far from being a great memorable black IPA.

12 oz from Als beer store in Dupont Circle area in DC.  Pours a deep, rich black with a cola-like fizz of head.  Aromas are of anise, honey, and woodiness.  Alcohol burn is evident in the initial taste, but then a wonderful black licorice flavor takes over, mediated by tones of honey and cedar.  Body is full, palate complex, and mouthfeel sublime. Had this one at the ACBF 2011. Black colored brew. Very nice aroma of malts, chocolate and liquorice. Flavor has got all of those with a good bitterness. Some wood. Very nice chocolate flavor. Good!

12 ounce bottle purchased at American Spirits in St. Pete, FL.  The aroma is somewhat chocolatey with fair roastiness.  Light oxidation.  Light cedar woodiness is also there.  Pretty nice aroma.  Mildly transparent dark mahogany body with a mild light tan head.  Starts a bit metallic, and becomes chocolatey with significant roastiness in the middle.  Some ethanol is definitely present towards the end.  Finishes with a nice woodiness from the cedar.  Some late astringency is also there.  This is more of an Imperial Stout.  I find it strange that this is called a black IPA.  At 11.2%, really?

(Bottle) Pours black with a small and creamy brown head. The aroma is burned (with round edges) and mild honey-ish alongside tones of dried dark fruits, fruity cocoa, citric/resinous/metallic hops and some spicy wood. Hints of salt liquorice, ginger, pepper, vanilla, wet asphalt, alcohol and dark syrup. The flavour is light to medium sweet, medium to heavily bitter and tiny acidic. Pours jet black with a tan head. Aroma is faint hoppyness with citrus. Taste is funky honey, citrus, hoppyness. Palate is good with a decent warming ability. Overall a good beer.

17-APR-2011, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
Tasted side by side with "OR".
Pours very very dark brown with light brown head. Head not as high as wiht "or" but perhaps the pour was not equal? But it happens again with the second pour.

Pours dark brown, off white head. Aroma had candied dark fruit, caramel, some cedar and honey. Taste is sweet caramel, dark fruit, lots of cedar and honey, with some sweet aged hops, slightly dry finish

Bottled.  Poured higher-viscosity deep brown with a dusting and a ring of tan head.  The aroma picked up a rich blend of toasted dark malts and honey with a bit of a candied twist to it.. spicy pine and black peppery accents.. very warm and sweet on the back of the nose.  The flavor found a more intense kick from the pine and earthy hops plus peppery cedar, but the malts still drive it.. honey and ashy black malts along with cedar and floral bitterness on the long, bitter finish.  Heavier-bodied with lots of malt, a little less hoppage, and ample cedar on the palate.. a little more candied than Id like, but it was a very interesting brew.
(Bottle 16/3-2011) A bit more sweet and full in the taste then Or, low head, bitter. A bit much ABV for the overall taste.

12 oz bottle from Capones. Poured a basically flat oily black body with a smaller dark brown foamy head that is only visible with super vigorous agitation. Aroma is a huge let down. Super boozy, earthy, sweet syrup, dark fruit.......highly reminds me of WWS. Sickengly thick syrupy body with soft super small tight bubbly carbonation. Flavor of dirt, earth, booze, card board, alcohol. Wow total let down.

Appearance: black and viscous. A fluffy espresso crema head leaves a collar bordering crema bubbles. Swirls thick along the edges, no lace, and a thin sheen of crema foam lingers on topthen disappears.

Nose: fudgy, roasty, dark fruits  meaty & chewy. Thick caramel nougat. Vanilla bean along edges. Cooked than cooled honey melts into and with the nougat. Woody earthiness with a hint of char and tar. Bacony greasy smoky essence in the back; like standing in front of a smoker, oily. Rooty. Tar balls. Figs, dates, prunes.

Palate: grabs top center of tongue and never lets go. Not as thick as expected  soft, frothy, almost cakey mouthfeel. Burnt finish builds with ash, burnt black cacao. Honey and fudge, caramel and toffee. Sweet smoke in the back. Cinnamon sticks in the breath. Meaty dark fruits join finish  prunes and figs especially. Fast procession of flavor with each quaff is intense and continues from first quaff to last. More burnt wood and ash. Mouth starts to water as it dries. Dryness of tannins  wood and leather. Has a sense of brewing times past. Bakers chocolate. The honey is a subtle touch  more cooked than fresh. Warmth grows in chest and breath. Salty umami savoriness.

Final Thoughts: wow and wow. Definitely a sipper but a fine sipper at that. Beer boring? Paf! Beer is living and beer is tasty and oh my goodness how I love it. Pour, let warm to room temperature, and savor. A limited dual release, if you happen to find a bottle dont be afraid to savor all by your lonesome.

12 oz bottle from Beerlando. Thanks, Bryan! Part 1! Pours a blackish opaque pour, dark and ominous with a big frothy brown head that cakes and laces well. Stays quite large and solid. Aromas are some big hop bitterness, citrus and florals mix with resinous pine, some roasted malts and a big raisiny dark fruit element. Touches of honey, sweet caramel, toffee, with some spicy woody cedar, chocolate, and more dry hops. Initial is fuller bodied, a nice roasty start with sweet honey, raisins and dark fruit meshing with caramel, PacNW hops throw citrus, pine, and florals blend into sweet malts, the roast fades back with raisins, honey, and some cocoa, sweet caramel and roast back in. The hops fade out a bit as the beer gets a bit big and sweet, sticky caramel and raisins. Roast and cocoa. Ok, perhaps there is a bit of age on it.. But it really is quite sweet into the finish for my liking, some toasty cedar does work through though. Ok, a well made beer, but has its sweetness getting a bit cloying. An ok beer, but Im baffled as to how this is Top 3 in this category.

I was baffled by Or when I had it the first time, I preferred Or to Either when I had them side by side, but now this tastes better than I remember any of them. All I can determine is that they are both very well-crafted ales that Im glad to have tried.

Sampled February 2011
A vigorous pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a four-finger thick, nicely brown stained, dark tan colored head.  The head leaves lots of layered lacing on the sides of my glass as it slowly subsides.  The beer is a concentrated, dark-chocolate brown color that is quite opaque when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of slightly dirty, tangelo zest, lychee and sweet ruby-red grapefruit juice; I say dirty because a backdrop of roasted malt contributes a burnt edge as well as an earthy quality to what would otherwise be a bright hop fruitiness.  The hops also seem to contribute a woodiness that reminds me a bit of pine, but a bit more spicy and I realize that this is likely accentuated by the cedar used in this brew.  The cedar is actually fairly subtle and from the nose I wouldnt have guessed it was here if I didnt already know about it as it melds quite well with the hop notes.  Touches of cocoa are found here and, in combination with the hops, remind me of orange flavored truffles; at times the chocolate aromatics can be quite prominent, but usually the hops are the clear dominant note in the nose.

This has a rich creamy texture to it as it first hits my tongue; this accentuates a rich chocolate flavor found in the middle of this beer, but this morphs into a bitter roast character in the finish.  The hop character contributes the bulk of the bitterness in this beer, but the roast malt definitely contributes as well.  Lingering herbal and pine notes also linger in the finish and are actually found through out the flavor profile of this beer (though it is more noticeable towards the finish of a sip than at the beginning).  The bright hop fruitiness of the nose is not nearly so prominent in the flavor; the roast in combination with the hop character contributes notes of lightly burnt fruit (tangelo zest, orange zest, grapefruit towards the middle and finish, and some lychee / tropical fruit notes that seem to get muted quite a bit by the roasted character) .  Some spicy, warming alcohol is noticeable towards the finish and seems to mix in with a spicy, woody note that must be contributed by the cedar.  There is quite a bit of roast character to this beer; it contributes a rich toasted whole grain note, a toasted spicy rye note (which is likely quite influenced by the cedar), some full city roast coffee bean notes that lean towards earthy, and some bitter roast coffee notes towards the finish.  The body of this beer is actually fairly rich, it seems to have a lot more texture than the Or and is most definitely a beer to be savored and sipped; it perhaps drinks a little lighter than its actual strength, but not by a whole lot.

Definitely a tasty beer, it seems a bit less hop focused (at least in the flavor), or you could say more malt balanced, than the Or.  I am not quite too sure which one I have enjoyed more.  As in the Or, the roast malt, alcohol, cedar and hops can combine to be a touch harsh, though not overly so.

 Preferred the "Or" slightly more.

Beer A: bottle thanks to Drowland, sampled side by side blind(with Or), pours dark brown to black with a medium tan head that leaves a light lacing down the glass. Very herbal or spruce in nature.  I like this, its a huge beer, but drinks more like one I could drink a few pints of.

Chocolate, coffee and hops dominate the aroma.  Deep brown in color with a tan head.  Smooth, coating, coating chocolate/coffee with an IPA hoppiness.  Very much an IPA-like stout.

Notes: Bottle at Alvinne CBF 11

Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, liquorish, coffee and citrus hop. Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol, chocolate, liquorish, coffee and citrus hop. Medium bitter.

Bottle, bought @ Skjold Burne, Aarhus.

I know that Either/Or are similar but I definitely found this to be my preference.  The hop profile here seems more robust and the flavors seem to meld together easily.  Same dark mahogany pour.  Same well hidden ABV.
Dark black, small head smell is floral, hops, sweet coffee. Taste about the same, a bit to floral but not bad at al.

Flaske: Denne øl løb lidt sammen med or. Sort gennemsigtig øl med et fint skumhoved. Duften er humlet men der kan bestemt anes honing i den. Smagen er igen humledomineret men med et tydeligt præg af honing uden det bliver for sødt. God øl.

12oz bottle my brother brought back from Tampa, thanks Jeff! Compared side-by-side with "Or." Pours a black body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, darker brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is very similar to the "Or," but a tad bit richer in the malts and sweeter in the citruses. Heavy caramels, tons of toasted cedar, juicy and piney citruses, lots of tobacco, some roast, spiced earth, cocoa, resins, and a touch of bread. Flavor is sweet caramels with lots of juicy, citrus pines up front. Tons of charred cedar come in with lots of roasts, tobacco, and dry cocoas. This does maintain more of a sweetness and hop juiciness than the "Or," but they are very close. Lots of bitter orange peel comes out towards the end along with some spices, more earth, and a touch of bread as this finishes very dry and bitter with tons of biting and resiny pines, juicy citruses, toasted cedar, heavy roasts, and tobacco all balanced nicely by a solid caramel and cocoa. Very lengthy aftertaste following a medium, very soft and creamy, almost full body with a soft, creamy, medium carbonation. Overall, this beer along with the "Or" are right up my alley. Toooons of bold flavors all balanced extremely well with an exceptional palate. This one leans a tad bit towards the sweeter pines and citruses. Very similar to the "Or," but just a tick beneath it IMO. Nonetheless, so damn good.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2011 Bottled. Pours almost opaque, black with a medium sized, creamy, beige head. Excellent lacings. Nose of dark chocolate, dark fruits and pine needles. Medium sweet flavour of roasted malts, dark fruits, coffee and pine needles. Full bodied. Flat carbonation. Oily texture. More dry and bitter finish. Delicious and an interesting brew.

Bottle. Pours a bitch black color with a small tan head. Aroma is of citrussy hops, pine, cedar, faint honey, roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is of the toasted cedar along with some citrussy hops, roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, honey and some resin. The body is medium with a nice creamy mouthfeel. Overall a nice Black IPA, though I prefer the Or.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2011 Wow. This is so full. Pitch black pour with minimal head. Nose is of cedar, chocolate and a little of the NW hops. Full bodied and pretty straight forward. This has more body and cedar coming through than the OR. Really doesnt go anywhere and leaves me scratching my head with the high score. Maybe in Winter in the states this would translate better. Nice but more of a strong ale than a black IPA.

Huge thanks to Jefe73 for sending this my way!

A- Body is a dark, aboding motor oil black hue. Pours with a 1-2 finger creamy dark tan head. Honestly-this brew has big imperal stout written all over it in the appearance- Lacing left all the way down the glass.

S- The nose is very interesting and quite contrasting. Imperial coffee stout meets DIPA-lots of grapefruit, citrus, roasted malt, the smallest hint of wood, dark chocolate, and a hint of alcohol.

T- Smooth creamy dark chocolate and woody flavors highlight (somewhat) upfront, minimal honey and cedar-accents of citrus above this. The finish is much more stout than IPA as well-with roasted malt and smooth dark chocolate and a hint of wood/honey coming through. What lingers is crazy moderate to strong hop bitterness and a hint of roasted malt bitterness-actually its hard to tell the difference between the battling bitterness

M- Medium to high carbonation. Moderate to heavy weight sticky, oily body. The hop oils mix in well here.

D-This is probably the most complex black ale I have had yet. The hop/malt contrast here is huge (and weird of course-but thats just the style). Overall this is good-but a little bitter for my tastes. Mouthfeel is phenomenal. THIS makes me look forward to some Hill Farmstead

Serving type: bottle

Bottle. Almost pitch black and opague. Grassy herbal aroma with honey and licorice. Some woody notes. Malty roasty salty flavor, sweet with honey, hints of wood and licorice. The wood lingers on in the aftertaste.

This one is good.  Best Black IPA Ive had to date.  First sip hits you with lots of honey.  This is the less hoppy of the two currently available in this colab series, hard to access but well worth picking up if you can.

Dark, black. Has a light brown head, mostly lasting. Complex aroma, nice and unpleasent at the same time, ceder and sweet, roasted malts. Perfect flavor, unitity of sweetness, acidic, and bitterness. The ceder-tree is perfect in the flavor, makes it a dry, aromatic liquid. Dry, creamy texture.
soft cedre aroma and nice hoppy,black, brown foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish, nice soft beer.

12oz. bottle, with a big thanks to GodOfThunder for one from a sweet load of CC goodness!  Pours pitch black with a moderate creamy tan head.  Aroma is quite nice, with a hops leading the way, pine/resin, some sharp citrus, grass, cedar, molasses, and a little honey.  Flavor is dominated by a great balance of pine, cedar, a little chocolate, honey and molasses.    Man, I love what these guys do with cedar; when it works, it really works!  Thanks again to GOT, much appreciated J!
Almost black with a small beige head. Slightly hoppy, chocolate fugey, some mud pie. Some booze and warming alcohol, but overall a good black ale though it is on the light side with the hops.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2011 Bottle. Medium high long lasting light brown creamy head. Absolutely no light coming through this black body. Lovely. Slightly bitter sour coffee cocoa caramel aroma. Powerful coffee liquorice cocoa caramel hops bitter flavor. High carbonation. Long bitter aftertaste. Alcohol well hidden. Impressive.

Bottle shared with some BA/RB folk (thanks to Beerlando for sending this our way)...  Poured black with a slightly off-white head.  Nose had lots of cedar on it with a slight sweetness.  Thicker palate compared to its counterpart.  The honey shined more with a decent malt body and nice mesh of hop and toasted cedar tones.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, Feb. 2011. Pours black with a small creamy beige head and lacings. Nose is liquorice, roast and honey. Smooth and full bodied. Cedar, roast and hops. Smooth, stikcy and oily. Cedar and apple notes in the end.

Black with a small but lasting tan head. Aroma of licorice, tropical fruit, cedar wood and vanilla. Sweet licorice dominated flavour with citrus hops, a bit of wood and plenty alcohol. A bit of resin, but less wood than the Or version, which also seemed more balanced

Bottle. Moderate toasted and molasses for the malt, heavy pine for the hops moderate leather for the yeast, with tar and licorice in the background. Head is small, creamy, light brown with good slippery lacing and good legs, and is mostly diminishing. Color is black. Flavor is moderately sweet and lightly acidic to start, and the long finish is lightly sweet and acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy with a soft carbonation and a sticky finish. An excellent mix of flavors and aromas in this Black IPA. I liked this one better than its Or brother.

pours very black with a medium sized creamy mocha head...very nice retention and lacing.  aroma is very roasty with some black licorice, dark fruit, faint citrus, notable cedar notes, and some alcohol.  flavor has some sweet honey and dark fruit up front with some very roasty and slightly smoky flavors following.  very hoppy with subtle grapefruit and spice.  mouthfeel is somewhat thick and silky.  finish drys out with roasty cedar and lingering hops...warming.  excellent beer!
Bottle from Skjold Burne. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, coffee, chocolate, licorice, caramel and hops. Quite syropy.

WOW! Delicious beer! Aroma was nice. Strong roasted malt and a hint of grassy hops. Pour was a flat black with no bubbles and no head. Very beautiful reddish hues when held to the light. Taste was outstanding. I wouldve thought this was an impy, but there was a strong grassy hoppiness that balanced out the deep rich roasted malt. A strong licorice character gave the beer a thick and chewy mouthfeel yet the light carbonation made it extremely drinkable. Just a hint of wood is evident as the beer warms. My first CC beer and very impressed!

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2014 Pours black with a brown head. Aroma of honey, wood, caramel, roasted malts and piney hops. Big taste on this one. I got coffee, roasted malts, dark bitter chocolate, wood, honey, spicey notes (pepper), piney hops and warming alcohol leading to a dry bitter end.
Black pour with tan head and lace. Aroma of sour malt, coffee, and abv. Sour mal, sweet chocolate, and a very nice eartht/citrus bitter finsh. full bodied with good carbonation. very nice

overall: def prefer the or moreso than either with its more pronounced hop profile and the cedar providing extra character.

Bottle. Thanks Hopscoth for this trade. It pours opaque black with a medium tan head. The aroma is hard roasted malt, sweet peachy fruit. light smoke, honey, liquorice, pine and light chocolate. The flavour is very intense. Notes of cedar, honey, spicy and fruity hops, toasted malt, sweet caramel and piney hops. Long sweet fruity and roasted finish with some warming alcohol. Thanks riversideak!  Love the spicy cedar nose, little mint......not super hoppy.  Dark brown, small tan head.  The chewy cedar balances nicely with the milk chocolate body, I demand more cedar in beer.

Bottle: thanks to Joes for sharing:
Small brown head on top of black beer with a red shine.

Aroma: Coconut, vanilla, mint and dried tropical fruit.

Mouthfeel: Thick, syrupy with average carbonation.

Bottle at Sune.
Black coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel, roasted bread, hops and pine needles.

Pours almost black with a small beige head. Smells of sprucy hops and chocolate. Sweet with aromas of dark fruits. Also lots of spruce hops aromas. Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Dark fruits finish.

Bottle at Sunes. Black - brown head. Burned malts. Chocolate. Sweetness. Nice hoppy. Bitterness. Coffee. Raisins. Light ceder. Light wooden. Light tartness. Peppery. Light flowery. Is it a black IPA, a hoppy porter or a light Imp. Stout ?

12 oz. brown bottle  thanks to 50belair. A very thick very black beer with a small head. The aroma is strong with hops, citrus, very green smelling, and the alcohol is pretty noticeable. The taste has some tar, chocolate, ash, pine, and I cant say I taste honey with all the hops going on. As it warms up I can taste the cedar that seems to add a dry finish. Low to medium carbonation and the mouthfeel was thick and slick as it slides down your mouth. I thought OR was a little better.

Common Rating for Either Black Ale  and Or Black Ale
In short: Big boozy roasted chocolaty beer with aggressive green and resinous bitterness.  Good sipper.
How: Bottles 12oz (Either + Or) side by side, fresh, about 1 month after the beers release
The look: Black body topped by a medium beige head leaving good lacings.  Either version has a slightly better head retention.
Mostly common between OR and EITHER versions: Uber-hoppy nose with a very fresh green hop peletts signature.  Taste has chocolate, medium roasted level, some dry wood.  There is a little toasted wood notes that dry out the beer a bit but I would not have guessed this was cedar barrels aged.  Very assertive bitterness that is both citrusy and resinous.  Appropriately smooth carbonation.  Tasty aggressive beer that are nonetheless pleasant to drink.
Differences between OR and EITHER versions: Either was more chocolaty and had a richer fuller body.  Or version had more honey sweetness.  Alcohol was a bit more apparent in Or version and was a bit bothersome. 
Bottom line: I found the Either (8-4-7-4-15=3.8) more interesting than the Or (8-3-7-3-14=3.5).  Im surprised by this result because I usually much prefer Hill Farmstead products over Cigar City.  The girlfriend and I drank both beers in presence of the Hill Farmstead assistant brewer.  He was very curious to know my opinion.  I told him the truth that I preferred the Cigar City version.  My mother always told me that it cost nothing to be honest.  And my father also told me that stealing peoples wallets not only costs nothing but can also generate a little profit.  Thanks dad!
Bottle from changeup45. Large amounts of roasted malts with some chocolate and a hint of woody earthiness....which I guess would be the cedqr. Interesting beer. Good stuff.

Bottle thanks to bigmmartin.  Aroma is hoppy with chocolatey sweet malts.  Notes of cedar, leather, a little vanilla, and some earthy tones stand out.  Palate is smooth, espicially considering the alchol level.  Flavor really brings out a cigar type quality, guessing it is the cedar.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2012 Originally rated on 1.2.2011 - 330ml bottle from Bierkompass

Pours pitch black with a small foamy head. Aroma has hints of roasted malts and honey. Extremely well balanced taste has hints of roasted coffee, chocolate and fruits. Smooth palate with a bitter finish. Excellent Black DIPA. 9-4-9-4-16 = 4.2

Re-rated on 12.6.2012. 330ml bottle from Barley Wine, Copenhagen. Wow, this is still a real treat. Getting a lot of tobacco and wooden notes from this bottle. Still extremely well balanced and tasty.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a pitch black colour with a creamy, lacy dark brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, very smooth dark chocolate and also mild coffee. Flavour of very smooth dark chocolate again, raspberries, coffee and strong hops in a perfect balance. Full bodied with a slick mouthfeel and a warming, very smooth and round finish with chocolate notes. Best Black IPA Ive tasted so far.

Bottle via Glouglouburp.  Pours dark brown/black with a nice solid sheet of light brown atop.  spicy, musty cedar in the nose along with toasty malts in a  rye smelling way (likely the cedar influence) and some hops as well.  Lovely toasty nose though regardless of whats causing it.  DId I mention I love cedar?  Big cedar influence in the flavors...thick body, sweet toasty malts with a little touch of bitter chocolate.  This one is a bit over the top with the cedar compared with the "Or" which I seem to have liked a bit more.  That being said, this is still pretty damn good as I still like the cedar...just could be toned down a tad.

Nose is full of sweetness, honey, cedar, almost underattenuated possibly with lots of sugars. Dark brown almost black pour, thin beige ring, light lace. Flavors are sweet, lots of honey sweetness, spicy cedar, black malts, earthy hops, black pepper. Lots of sugary sweetness dried out by the cedar. Slightly alcoholic, too sweet, dries out in finish. Lingering cedar. Its ok.

12oz bottle, thanks Alex and Dave.  Thicker bodied black pour with rich tan head.  Roasted caramel and chocolate, honey  infused with licorice, light hoppy sweetness...very subtle cedar as it warms.  Sweet, syrupy, underatenuated, hints of tart and metallic settling in...finish has a fair amount of hop bittering as well as cedar.  More like a stout for me.

Pretty much a hoppy stout, rather than a Black IPA (Or leaned more towards that territory).  This beer poured a dark brown, nearing black, with a tan head.  The aroma was caramel and chocolate malt, nice and rich, with some herbal hoppiness.  The hops are mild, relative to Or, though both rely on malt more than hops.  The taste is fairly sweet.  It seemed somehow similar to previous CCB stouts that Ive tried.  Fairly chewy and sweet.  Enjoyable beer.

Thanks to dchmela for this one.  Pours almost black. Thick tan head that lingers for a bit.  Nose of licorice, black cherry, brown sugar, raisin and chocolate.  Tastes of dark fruits, semi-sweet chocolate, raisin, and just enough hop to finish it off.  Medium to heavy body. Very, very nice.

12oz Bottle next to Or thanks to ditmier. Pours out black topped with a sans head. Aroma was of pine, roast malts, and citrus hops. Taste was more of the citrus, pins, and some floral hops, along with some roast malts and a little sweetness. I want to say this is the first CC 12oz bottle I have had.

Bottle from Dosbeerigos. Dark brown with tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with some toasty woody notes, biscuits and mild honey. Taste has a nice sweetness with some nice roasted malts and a nice hop finish. Very nice.

Purchased at Sunset Corners in Miami. flavor is an interesting toasted hoppiness, the cedar woodiness is subtle but adds tot he smoked bar-b-cue gist. Slightly sweet, but I though it wasnt as good or full bodied as the Or.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 Honey and bright wood noticeable in aroma immediately upon pour from 12 oz bottle, thanks to kmweaver. Deepest brown opaque with huge tan billowing tight-beaded head. A moderate American hop piney-resin and tobacco aroma comes on too. Flavor leads with elegant brown sugar and dark malt complexity, with chewy, leathery notes, and just-lean-of-medium body. Robust porter-like flavors followed by a welcome alcohol warmth and a load of American hop flavor. This one finishes out with a rewarding bitter and dry balance.  [Either goes from a moderate aroma to a bursting flavor complexity, whereas Or goes from an exaggerated hop aroma to thinning flavor.]
Bottle courtesy of JRedmond.  Had back to back samplings of Either then Or.  I was blown away by this one.. Dont remember all the particulars but it was dark and tasted awesome.. rich ipa.
Strong, sweet caramel aroma with an equally strong hop aroma.  Flavor is sweet, almost cloying, with more strong green hops.
Bottle. Pours a jet black oil with a medium brown head. Scent is dark malts, pine, dark chocolate. Creamy feel. Nice smokey bitter taste with bitter dark chocolate. Fantastic!

The hops are much more muted in the aroma and flavor than the Or. Chocolate, some dark fruit with edges of of hop bitterness and some spice. A fair bit of sweetness. Pretty nice. Not too hot at this point.

Draft at redlight and from 12 oz bottle. Had this side by side with the Or version. This is the Florida version with the 2 row pale malt and pellet hops. This pours a pitch black color and topped by a pillowy head of mocha colored foam that shows great retention. Sticky rings of lace cling to the glass. This almost looks like a stout in the glass. The aroma is full of chocolate roast while helps balance out the huge citrus and grassy hop bitterness. Some spicy cedar comes through on the back end along with subtle notes of tobacco and honey. The flavor follows suit and shows the rich and roast chocolate malt base along with notes of sweet honey, dark fruits, and tobacco. The grassy hops add ample bitterness while the cedar adds a nice spicy character as well. The huge malt bill balances out the hop bitterness really nicely. Full bodied, round, and smooth with balanced carbonation that leads to a slightly sticky and roasty finish. This is a really nice and tasty black ipa and a little more well rounded than the Or version. Really good beer.

Pours black/dark brown.  Some head and lace.

Aroma is malt forward, more brown ale/toast than stout/roast.  With a hop accent.  

Taste is similar to aroma.  Like a hopped-up, rich, brown ale.  The hops are somewhat muted.  More piney than fruity.  No sense of high abv in this whatsoever.

This is more of a super rich brown ale with hops whereas Or is more of an ipa with an excessive amount of toasted malts and grains.  

Either and Or are a sort of yin and yang in that each is more of the opposite side of the same coin than the other.

12oz Bottle thanks to SFLpunk.
Appearance : Pitch black with a small foamy head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Citrusy and tropical hops. More hops than Or. Roasted malt and cedar.

Taste :  Nice tropical hops with cedar. Light roasted malt. Light tropical fruits on the finish. Quite bitter with cedar. Rather dry. 

Overall : Even better balanced than Or. Better hops. Very nice experiment.

Rated The or version and were very pleased. This either sjokke bf The cigar City version. The pour is just as black with a small Brown head. The nose is fresh and mild hoppy with a rosted profile. Pours black with a quickly fading tan lace.  Nose of green hops, butter, syrup, molasses, roasted malt, light wood/cedar.  Disjointed, with pockets of astringent green hoppiness and charry, woody cedar amidst roasted malts and burt cocoa. 12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark black with a very small tan head leaving lots of small spots of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is pine and citrus hops with orange peel and grapefruit, very light tobacco, and light coffee.  Initial taste is sweet with roasted malt and pine hops, then some citrus.  Finish is light coffee and light tobacco with a light bitterness.  Full bodied.  Low carbonation.  Great beer.  Enjoyed a little bit more than Or.  Seemed to be a bit smoother with a little less tobacco flavors.

Bottle from Bhiner41. Thanks!  Pours a jet black with a tan head and plenty of lacing.  Aroma is hoppy and sweet and a little roasty.  A bit heavy on the palate with medium carbonation.  Flavor is roasted malt, hops, coffee, and some cedar.  Seems like a hoppy imperial stout to me, although not quite.  Probably the best BIPA/CDA I have tried so far.  Looking forward to the Or later this week.

This black ale, like the or, pours dark thick coffee black with a great creamy cinnamon dark caramel head. The aroma is less boozy but sweet with notes of light roastiness and hops. The flavor is sweet malts with some whisky/bourbon notes. The body is creamy and smooth and the light hops settle nicely on the palate.
tap at Blind tiger - good dark IPA, piney hops, roasted chocolate malts, brown sugar that sticks to the lips. resinous hops, dry finish. tasty.

bottle side by side with Or.  deep black pour with a 1/4" tan head.  spicy / citrus hop nose (more subtle than Either) with a touch of wood.  medium body with the cedar notes up front, a solid bitterness over the top and lighter fruit notes down the sides.  warming finish with citrus and cedar towards the back.  the sweetness from the honey comes through on the back end as well. Super dark pour, with an off brown bubbly head. Chocolate malt aroma, with a slight hop presence. Bitter flavor with hints of dark  chocolate, malts, sugar. Has pretty good carbonation with good head retention. I would have liked a little more hop presence, but it was still good.

Nearly opaque black color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of pine, roasted notes, floral hops, citrus, resin, and chocolate.  Taste of pine resin, tobacco, citrus, roast, cocoa, grapefruit, and a dry, hoppy finish.

12 oz. bottle via trade with smith4498 - Pours a dark brown color with a one finger thick tan head.  Aroma is floral and citrus hops with some light roasted malt.  Flavor is much of the same.  Medium to full body.  Very good beer.  Thanks Jason.
Bottle pours dark brown/black with a tan head.  Aroma of cedar, chocolate, pine, smoke, coffee.  Flavor has all of the elements of above.  11.2% well hidden, thick flavorful beer.  Well done.
(12oz bottle thanks to Cavie) near black, medium tan soapy edge bubbles. Nose of cedar, chocolate, nutty, and very woody. Taste of huge cedar wood esters, medicinal, just weird.

black pour with a tan head.  Aroma is significant hop, relatively grassy in nature, and malt character that is biscuit, roast  is light but present.  Flavor is boozy, biscuit, caramel, intense hoppy resins.  fucking good

Black pour with a tan head. The nose is huge citrus resin and biscuit dough with pine and florals. The flavor is bready caramel and tootsie pop with super grapefruit and lemon-head hop notes.The palate is rich, thick, and resinous with a sticky finish.
12 ounce thanks to smith4498. Slightly stoutish body. Mix of chocolate milk, smoke, molasses. I found this one to be less intense than Or.

The body is massive with fairly light carbonation and a super long finish that runs the gamut from honey sweet, to hops citrus, to roasted bitterness.

Tap at BT.  Pours a bit darker than the Or.  Deep black with a darker tan head.
